content.text: An **axiomatic system** builds all theorems from a small set of self-evident axioms using rules of inference. This approach, pioneered by Euclid for geometry, was applied to logic by Frege, Russell, and Hilbert.

content.definition: A formal system consisting of: (1) a set of axioms (formulas accepted without proof), and (2) rules of inference for deriving new theorems from axioms and previously proven theorems.

content.text: A key property we want is **independence**: no axiom should be derivable from the others. If an axiom can be proven from the rest, it's redundant. Logicians seek minimal axiom sets.

content.title: Classical Axiom Schemas
content.note: These three schemas, with Modus Ponens, are sufficient to derive all propositional tautologies.

content.text: Natural deduction (which we've been using) is an alternative to axiomatic systems. It has more rules but no axioms, making proofs more intuitive. Both approaches are equivalent in power.

content.question: What is an axiom in a formal system?
options: A formula that must be proven first
content.explanation: Axioms are the starting points — formulas we accept as true without requiring proof. All other theorems are derived from them using inference rules.
